name: Finding area of polygons by decomposing and composing to solve real-world problems

skills.name: Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units
Calculate compound area involving rectangles, squares and triangles, where the dimensions are given in the same units

explanations.A: The area of the rectangle is 4 Ã— 6 = 24mÂ². The base of the triangle is 10 â€“ 6 = 4m, so the area of the triangle is Â½ Ã— 4 Ã— 4 = 8mÂ². The total area of turf is 24mÂ² + 8mÂ² = 32mÂ².
explanations.B: I think you have forgotten that the formula for the area of a triangle is Â½ Ã— base Ã— height. Start by working out what the base of the triangle would be.
explanations.C: I think you have used 10m as the base of the triangle, but that is the base of the whole shape. The base of the whole shape is 10m and the length of the top of the shape is 6m, what must the base of the triangle be?
explanations.D: I think you have started to find the perimeter of the turf rather than the area. Remember: Area of a rectangle = base Ã— height. Area of a triangle = Â½ Ã— base Ã— height

explanations.A: I think you have started to find the perimeter of the turf rather than the area. Remember: Area of a rectangle = base Ã— height. Area of a triangle = Â½ Ã— base Ã— height
explanations.B: I think you have used 13m as the height of the triangle, but that is the height of the whole shape. Have another look at the diagram, what is the height of just the triangle?
explanations.C: I think you have forgotten that the formula for the area of a triangle is Â½ Ã— base Ã— height.
explanations.D: The area of the rectangle is 6 Ã— 9 = 54mÂ². The base of the triangle is 6m, so the area of the triangle is Â½ Ã— 6 Ã— 4 = 12mÂ². The total area of turf is 54mÂ² + 12mÂ² = 66mÂ².

explanations.A: I think you have forgotten that the formula for the area of a triangle is Â½ Ã— base Ã— height.
explanations.B: It looks like you have used 7 as the height for the top triangle, but that is the height of the whole shape. Think about how you can work out the height of just the triangle.
explanations.C: The flag has been split into two triangles and a rectangle. The area of the rectangle is 8 Ã— 4 = 32ğ‘–ğ‘›Â². The top triangle has a height of 7 â€“ 4 = 3ğ‘–ğ‘›, so the area is Â½ Ã— 8 Ã— 3 = 12ğ‘–ğ‘›Â². The bottom triangle has a base of 14 â€“ 8 = 6ğ‘–ğ‘›, so the area is Â½ Ã— 6 Ã— 4 = 12ğ‘–ğ‘›Â². The total area of the flag is 32 + 12 + 12 = 56ğ‘–ğ‘›Â²
explanations.D: It looks like you thought the flag was a triangle with base 14 and height 7 but the flag actually has 4 sides. Have another look at the flag; it has been split into a rectangle and 2 triangles. You can find the area of each of these separately and then add them together for the area of the flag.

explanations.A: The sail has been split into two triangles and a rectangle. The area of the rectangle is 10 Ã— 8 = 80ğ‘“ğ‘¡Â². The top triangle has a height of 12 â€“ 8 = 4ğ‘“ğ‘¡, so the area is Â½ Ã— 4 Ã— 10 = 20ğ‘“ğ‘¡Â². The bottom triangle has a base of 18 â€“ 10 = 8ğ‘“ğ‘¡, so the area is Â½ Ã— 8 Ã— 8 = 32ğ‘“ğ‘¡Â². The total area of the sail is 80 + 20 + 32 = 132ğ‘“ğ‘¡Â²
explanations.B: It looks like you thought the sail was a triangle with base 18 and height 12 but the sail actually has 4 sides. Have another look at the sail; it has been split into a rectangle and 2 triangles. You can find the area of each of these separately and then add them together for the area of the sail.
explanations.C: I think you have forgotten that the formula for the area of a triangle is Â½ Ã— base Ã— height.
explanations.D: It looks like you have used 12 as the height for the top triangle, but that is the height of the whole shape. Think about how you can work out the height of just the triangle.

explanations.A: You have correctly worked out the total area of the wall including the window, but the window won't be painted. What do we need to do with the area of the window?
explanations.B: I think you have added the total area of the wall and window to the area of the window. Remember, the window will not be painted so we don't want to add it to the total area, what should we do with it instead?
explanations.C: I think you have subtracted the window lengths from the wall lengths and then multiplied to find the area. However this is not the correct order, you need to find the area of the whole wall and the area of the window first and then subtract the areas.
explanations.D: The area of wall to be painted, is the area of the whole wall, subtract the area of the window. This gives us: 8 Ã— 12 â€“ 3 Ã— 2 = 90ğ‘“ğ‘¡Â².

explanations.A: I think you have subtracted the entryway lengths from the floor lengths and then multiplied to find the area. However this is not the correct order, you need to find the area of the whole floor and the area of the entryway first and then subtract the areas.
explanations.B: The area of floor to be carpeted, is the area of the whole floor, subtract the area of the tiled entryway. This gives us: 9 Ã— 15 â€“ 3 Ã— 4 = 123ğ‘“ğ‘¡Â².
explanations.C: You have correctly worked out the total area of the floor including the entryway, but the entryway won't be carpeted. What do we need to do with the area of the entryway?
explanations.D: I think you have added the total area of the floor and entryway to the area of the entryway. Remember, the entryway will not be carpeted so we don't want to add it to the total area, what should we do with it instead?

explanations.A: You have worked out the area as if it was one large rectangle with base 10 and height 12, but there is part of that rectangle missing in the top right of the shape. Try splitting the shape into two smaller rectangles and work out each area separately.
explanations.B: One way to do this is to split the shape vertically into two rectangles. This gives us one rectangle of 3ğ‘“ğ‘¡ by 4ğ‘“ğ‘¡ and one rectangle of 12ğ‘“ğ‘¡ by 7ğ‘“ğ‘¡. The 7 has come from the width 10 â€“ 3. So the total area is: 3 Ã— 4 + 12 Ã— 7 = 96ğ‘“ğ‘¡Â²
explanations.C: I think you have done 7 Ã— 12 + 4 Ã— 10, but that means you are counting the area in the bottom left of the shape twice. If you split the shape horizontally to give the 4 Ã— 10 rectangle, what would the height of the top rectangle be?
explanations.D: I think you have split the shape horizontally and worked out 3 Ã— 12 + 4 Ã— 10. The rectangle at the bottom would be 4 Ã— 10 but the top rectangle would not have a height of 12 or a width of 3. You need to use the given heights of 12 and 4 to work out the height of the top rectangle, and the given widths of 10 and 3 to find the width of the top rectangle.

explanations.A: I think you have split the rectangle vertically into two rectangles and done 3 Ã— 10 + 4 Ã— 8. The rectangle on the left would be 3 Ã— 10 but the rectangle on the right would not have a height of 4 or a width of 8. You need to use the given heights of 10 and 4 to work out the height of the rectangle, and the given widths of 8 and 3 to find the width of the rectangle.
explanations.B: I think you have done 3 Ã— 10 + 8 Ã— 6, but that means you are counting the area in the top left of the shape twice. If you split the shape vertically to give the 3 Ã— 10 rectangle, what would the height of the top right rectangle be?
explanations.C: One way to do this is to split the shape vertically into two rectangles. This gives us one rectangle of 3ğ‘“ğ‘¡ by 10ğ‘“ğ‘¡ and one rectangle of 5ğ‘“ğ‘¡ by 6ğ‘“ğ‘¡. The 5 has come from the width 8 â€“ 3 and the 6 has come from the height 10 â€“ 4. So the total area is: 3 Ã— 10 + 5 Ã— 6 = 60ğ‘“ğ‘¡Â²
explanations.D: You have worked out the area as if it was one large rectangle with base 8 and height 10, but there is part of that rectangle missing in the bottom right of the shape. Try splitting the shape into two smaller rectangles and work out each area separately.

explanations.A: Almost! You have worked out the total area of the barn to be covered in paint but the question asks 'How many pots of paint will the farmer need?'.
explanations.B: I think you have forgotten that the formula for the area of a triangle is Â½ Ã— base Ã— height.
explanations.C: The height of the triangular part of the barn is 8 â€“ 5 = 3ğ‘š, so the area of the triangle is Â½ Ã— 20 Ã— 3 = 30ğ‘šÂ². The area of the rectangular part is 5 Ã— 20 = 100ğ‘šÂ². The total area to be painted is 30 + 100 = 130ğ‘šÂ². Each pot of paint covers 10ğ‘šÂ², so the farmer needs 130 Ã· 10 = 13 pots of paint.
explanations.D: I think you have used 8ğ‘š as the height of the triangular part of the barn but that is the height of the whole shape, which is made up of a triangle on top of a rectangle. You need to use the total height of the shape and the height of the rectangle to work out the height of the triangle.

explanations.A: The height of the triangular part of the garage is 10 â€“ 6 = 4ğ‘š, so the area of the triangle is Â½ Ã— 20 Ã— 4 = 40ğ‘šÂ². The area of the rectangular part is 6 Ã— 20 = 120ğ‘šÂ². The total area to be painted is 40 + 120 = 160ğ‘šÂ². Each pot of paint covers 10ğ‘šÂ², so Seth needs 160 Ã· 10 = 16 pots of paint.
explanations.B: I think you have used 10ğ‘š as the height of the triangular part of the garage but that is the height of the whole shape, which is made up of a triangle on top of a rectangle. You need to use the total height of the shape and the height of the rectangle to work out the height of the triangle.
explanations.C: Almost! You have worked out the total area of the garage to be covered in paint but the question asks 'How many pots of paint will Seth need?'.
explanations.D: I think you have forgotten that the formula for the area of a triangle is Â½ Ã— base Ã— height.
